block.p: Natalie Hancock Moore, a daughter of Carol S. Robbins of Simsbury, Conn., and Franklin H. Moore of Eastham, Mass., was married yesterday to Patrick Louis Clavette, a son of Elaine and Conrad Clavette of Harwinton, Conn. The Rev. Joanne Neel-Richard, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford.

Ms. Moore, 26, is keeping her name. She is a graphic designer with Studioworks, a graphic design studio in Avon, Conn., that is owned by her mother. She graduated from Tufts University. Her father is a broker with Wilkinson & Associates Real Estate in Orleans, Mass. The bride is a descendant of Salmon Portland Chase, who was Abraham Lincoln's first treasury secretary and later chief justice of the United States Supreme Court.

Natalie Hancock Moore, a daughter of Carol S. Robbins of Simsbury, Conn., and Franklin H. Moore of Eastham, Mass., was married yesterday to Patrick Louis Clavette, a son of Elaine and Conrad Clavette of Harwinton, Conn. The Rev. Joanne Neel-Richard, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford.

Ms. Moore, 26, is keeping her name. She is a graphic designer with Studioworks, a graphic design studio in Avon, Conn., that is owned by her mother. She graduated from Tufts University. Her father is a broker with Wilkinson & Associates Real Estate in Orleans, Mass. The bride is a descendant of Salmon Portland Chase, who was Abraham Lincoln's first treasury secretary and later chief justice of the United States Supreme Court.

Mr. Clavette, 31, is a materials engineer with International Fuel Cells in South Windsor, Conn., a manufacturing unit of the United Technologies Corporation. He graduated from the University of Connecticut at Storrs and received a master's degree in mechanical engineering from the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. His father is a lithographer with the Rondo Packaging Company, a design and manufacturing concern in Naugatuck, Conn.
